Headline.Para: Trump Allows Current Transgender Troops but Bans Future Recruits; President partially reverses himself after signing memo last year denying admission to transgender individuals

LeadPara.Para: WASHINGTONâ€”President Donald Trump partially reversed himself Friday and decided to allow many of the currently serving transgender people to remain in the armed forces, but he banned the future recruitment of most individuals who are considered transgender.

The White House said it has endorsed the recommendations of Defense Secretary Jim Mattis to permit some transgender service members to remain, in essence rescinding Mr. Trump's own tweets and memos last summer in which he said he would no longer allow transgender individuals to serve.

TailParas.Para: The administration decision comes amid federal court rulings requiring the Pentagon to maintain a policy of open transgender service.

The Justice Department was expected to file at least one motion Friday evening in U.S. District Court in the Western District of Washington state to argue the court should lift an injunction that prevented the Pentagon from banning transgender service members. The Trump administration faces a number of court orders that require the Pentagon to maintain the previous policy until they are reversed.
"DoD will continue to comply with court rulings and continue to assess and retain transgender service members," said Maj. Dave Eastburn, a Pentagon spokesman.
Mr. Trump's tweets last summer sought to reverse a 2016 order issued under Mr. Trump's Democratic predecessor that lifted a ban on openly transgender military-service members.

"I hereby revoke my memorandum of August 25, 2017â€¦and any other directive I may have made with respect to military service by transgender individuals," Mr. Trump wrote in a memorandum released by the White House late Friday. The memorandum referred to documents as well as tweets by the Republican president last year.

Under the new policy that took effect Friday, currently serving transgender service members may remain as long as they don't require a change in gender and are able to deploy, in line with one of Mr. Mattis's recommendations, according to U.S. officials familiar with the matter. Service members diagnosed with gender dysphoria since the previous administration's policy took effect, but before the effective date of the new policy, may also continue to serve in their preferred gender. Those individuals will also continue to receive medical treatment for their gender dysphoria, according to a memo written by Mr. Mattis.

The new policy would bar future enlistment by most recruits who have a condition, known as gender dysphoria, in which people suffer anxiety stemming from incompatibility between their biological gender and the gender with which they identify.

Those individuals will have to demonstrate that they have shown no symptoms of gender dysphoria for 36 months, meaning they have to show they are "gender stable" for three years, and still must enlist in the gender of their birth.

In his memorandum, Mr. Trump wrote that he deferred to Mr. Mattis and his advisers to determine the military's policy on transgender service. After several months of study, Mr. Mattis's recommendations bore some similarity to those of his predecessor, Ash Carter, who served under former President Barack Obama.

Mr. Mattis agreed to grandfather currently serving transgender service members largely because he believed it was the right thing to do, according to the U.S. officials. Also, they said, the Pentagon had already invested millions of dollars in training and retaining such individuals. Further, the Pentagon is trying to avoid having the court system dictate military personnel policy by settling on a policy before the courts act further, officials said.
There are 6,000 to 15,000 transgender service members, according to various estimates.
While the Defense Department alters policies with some regularity, one official said, it rarely does so without taking steps to grandfather those individuals who are affected.

In barring most future transgender recruits, Mr. Mattis agreed with the analyses that the medical treatment required a significant amount of down time, during which service members wouldn't be available to deploy, according to the U.S. officials. Mr. Mattis has emphasized the importance of members of the armed forces being "lethal" and able to be deployed.

The White House emphasized the risks it said are posed by transgender service members. "The secretary of Defense and the secretary of Homeland Security have concluded that the accession or retention of individuals with a history or diagnosis of gender dysphoriaâ€¦presents considerable risk to military effectiveness and lethality," said White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders in a statement.

Aaron Belkin, founding director of the Palm Center, a research and advocacy organization in California, said the ban on future transgender recruits reflected Mr. Trump's ideological goals and the Pentagon had distorted the science of transgender health.
"There is no evidence to support a policy that bars from military service patriotic Americans who are medically fit and able to deploy," he said. "Our troops and our nation deserve better."
